bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: Sacred Stories 08: Wisahketchahk and the Bear

p.seg:
kîtahtawê wîsahkêcâhk ,
hah , mahtih nik-ôsîhtân ; osâm kîtahtawê nikâ-mâkohikon kêkway , itêyihtam . Once upon a time Wisahketchahk thought, “Well, suppose I make some arrows; sometime something or other will drive me to close quarters.”
osîhtâw misâskwat ; osîhtâw acosisah . He prepared a saskatoon willow; he made some arrows.
kêkway kê-kînikâk êkotah kit-âstâyân , itêyihtam . “I ought to put something sharp on here,” he thought.
kîtahtawê miskam mistik , mihtah ôma tâpiskôc . Presently he found a stick of wood, like this faggot here.
tâpihtitâw mihcêt . he put them as tips on many arrows.

seg.gloss: “Why, to be the better prepared, I shall make also a spear;

p.seg: êwako mîna nik-ôsîhtân , itwêw . this too I shall make,” he said.

ê-kîsihtât ,
âh , mînah napakihkomân nik-ôsihtân ; When he had finished it, “Why, I shall make a broad-bladed knife, too;
osâm miywâsin awa mistik kit-ôh-osîhtâyân , itêyihtam . for this piece of wood is very good to make it of,” he thought.
osîhtâw môhkomân , napakihkomân . He made a knife, a broad-bladed knife.

êkwah ê-wâpahtahk onîmâskwâkanah ,
ptanê môskîstawit , môskistâkawiyân ! itêyihtam ; Then, when he looked upon his weapons, “I just wish he I just wish someone would attack me!” he thought; LB on {môskîstawit}: A slip of the tongue; the dictator corrects himself in the next word.
nama kêkway nika-kostên , itêyihtam . I shan't be afraid of anything,” he thought.
ê-kî-kîsihtât , sipwêhtêw . When he had finished them, he started out.
pasâhcâhk akâmihk êkotê wâpamêw wâkayôsah . At the other side of a ravine he saw a bear.
hâ , kiskêyihtam ê-macihtwâyit . Ha, he knew him for an ugly customer.
â , nika-kisîmaw , têpwâtak ; êkosi nika-nipahâw ; nika-mowâw , itêyihtam . “Ho, I shall make him angry by calling to him; then I shall kill him; I shall eat him,” he thought.

êkwah ômisi itêw :
awêna nâhâ ? têpwêw ,
kâ-wâpikiskicêt ! Then he called to him: “Who is that creature over there?” he shouted, “That white-rumped one!”
êh-pêhtahk awa wâkayôs , kisîmâw . When the bear heard that, he was angered.
mahtih tânitê kâ-têpwêhk ! itêyihtam . “Let me see from where this shouting comes!” he thought.
nam âwiya wâpamêw . He saw no one.
kâsôw wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk was hiding.

kîhtwâm êh-mônahikêyit ,
mahtih nka-kakwê-wâpamâw awâ kây-isit , itêyihtam . When the other was back at his digging, he thought, “Let me try and see him who is saying this to me.” LB: I.e., the bear; the next sentences are obscure because third person and obviative are not kept apart.
êkwah sîpâ ômisi tôtam , êh-wâtihkêt ; ôtêh osâpiw . Then down underneath there, he did like this, as he dug his pit; from here he looked forth.
pôtih kâ-pimi-sâkiskwêt . Sure enough, there he was, sticking out his head.
wâpamik âsay . Already the other saw him.
hawîna nâhâ kâ-wâpikiskicêt ! itêw . “Who is that white-rump over there? Pshaw!” he called to him.
hâw , wâpamêw ayîsiyiniwah ; môskîstawêw . Well, he saw a man; he made for him.
êkwah awa wîsahkêcâhk pîmakâmipitêw opîhtatwâna . Then that Wisahketchahk pulled round his quiver by the strap.
kisiwâk ôtay ê-pê-nakiyit , pimwêw . When the other came to a halt close by, he shot an arrow at him.
nâtwâhtin ôma mistik . That stick of wood fell broken as it struck.
wîpisisah piyisk mêstinam . Soon he used up all his arrows.
êhag , kâ-pa-pêyakonîmâskwêwinêhk kiy-ayîhtiyân , ka-kîh-wawânihih ! itêw . “Yes, yes, if I were the kind of person who carries only one weapon, you would be the finish of me!” he called to him.
otinam câpihcikanis ; tahkamêw . He took his spear; he jabbed at him.

êh-tahkamiht awa wâkayôs ,
mam ! itwêw . When the bear was hit with the spear, “Mum!” he went.
nâtwâhtitâw . It broke as he pushed it home.
kâ-pa-pêyakonîmâskwêwinêhk kîh-ayîhtiyân , ka-ki-wawânihih ! itêw . “If I were the kind of person who carries only one weapon, you would be the finish of me!” he told him.
tahkamêw ôm ôhci napakihkomân mistik ka-kîh-osihtât ; He made a stab at him with that flat knife which he had made out of a piece of wood;
nâtwâhtiniyiw . it broke lengthwise under the impact.

êkosi êkwah sêkihik ,
manitôww ! êy-itêyihtahk . At this, he grew afraid of the other, thinking, “He is supernatural!”
ncawâc nka-tapasîn , ê-nâtâmototahk itah ê-sakâyik . “I had better run away,” and he headed in panic for the woods.
mitoni kisiwâk askôk , êh-tâwatiyit . The other was close at his heels, with gaping jaws.
iyâpasâpici , kisiwâk askôk . Whenever he glanced back, the other was close upon him.
nîpisiya êh-asaskitêyikih , êkotah itâmôw . He fled to where some willows stood in a clump.
êkwah kâsispôkocin awa wâkayôs . The bear just missed as he jumped.
têtipêwêpayihôw wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk dashed round the trees.
kapê-kîsik êkotah wâsakâmêtisahok . All day long the other chased him round and round.
kîtahtawê nêyawapitwâwi , âyîtaw nîpawistâtôwak . Presently whenever the were out of breath, they would stand facing each other, at either side.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpomât êskanah , itah kâ-pâh-pimipahtât êkotah êh-môskatâwahkiskawât . Then at one time, he saw a horm from over which he had kicked loose the ground as he ran by.
nakîw . He stopped.
mân âwa wâkayôs wîmâskawêw , mana kontah ê-wâkastêyit awa wâkayôs . The bear always made a detour round it, taking a crooked course for no evident reason.
pâkâhkam awa wâkayôs kostêw , itêyihtam awa wîsahkêcâhk . “Plainly this bear is afraid of it,” thought Wisahketchahk.
mistahi nayôwapiw . He was badly out of breath.
awa mîna wâkayôs nayawapiw . The bear, too, was out of breath.
ncawâc tahkiskawêw wîsahkêcâhk ôhi kâ-kostimiht êskanah . Wisahketchahk tried kicking that horm, which was an object of fear.
piyisk pahkwaciwêpiskawêw . At last he knocked it lose with his foot, as he passed.

nicawâc êh-wîmâskawâyit ,
kostêw ! itêyihtam awa wîsahkêcâhk . When the other with plain intent made a circuit round it, “He is afraid of it!” thought Wisahketchahk.
otinêw ôhi êskanah . He seized that horn.
pakahkam awa kostêw ! itêyihtam . “Plainly he fears it!” he thought.

nicawâc ostikwânihk akonêw , ômisi êh-itât ôhi wâkayôsah :
hwhw ! êh-itât , kâ-wâki-kwâskohtiyit . He tried holding it on his head and saying “Hwoo!” to the bear, and there, the latter jumped off at an angle. LB on {hwhw}: Undulating velar or palatal spirant, with rounded lips; said to be the noise a buffalo makes when angry.
mahtih nika-môskîstawêw ! nayawapiw ! êh-itêyimât . “When he thought of the other, “Suppose I go for him! He is tired!”
tapasiyiwa . the other ran away.

iyâpasâpiyicih ôhi wâkayôsa , kisiwâk askôwêw ,
hwhw ! êh-itât . Whenever the bear glanced back, he was close upon him, saying, “Hwoo!”
êkosi mâna wîh-kakwê-mîhkawikîw . So he tried to run faster and faster.
piyisk wâpamêw wîsahkêcâhk ôhi wâkayôsah , pîstêw otôniyihk êw-ohcikawiyik . At last Wisahketchahk saw the foam dripping from the bear's mouth.

piyisk awa wâkayôs ,
kiyâm nika-wêpahok ! itêyihtam . At last the bear thought, “Well, he might as well toss me on his horn!”
kawipayihôw êkwah awa wîsahkêcâhk . And the bear threw himself flat on the ground. LB: Slip of the informant's tongue, or of my hand, for {wâkayôs}: “the bear,” and so translated.

ohtiskawapîstawêw ômis êh-itinât êskanah , ê-wîh-nipahatâhtamiyit , mayaw kêtâpamikocih ,
whwh ! êh-nimisîwihât . He sat down facing him, holding out the horn at him, like this, while the other was almost dead, puffing for want of breath, and every time the other looked at him, he threatened him, going “Hwoo!”
namoy âwa wîhkâc ta-waniskâw , nakatimakih ôhi nitêskanah , itêyihtam . “He will never get up, if I leave this horn of mine here,” he thought.

seg.q: hâw , wâkayôs ! mistahi kitêyimison , ayîsiyiniw miyâkohacih .
seg.gloss: “Now then, bear! You think a great deal of yourself, when you drive a man to close quarters.
But I, too, have something with which I can kill you.”

p.seg: tâwatiw wâkayôs , ispîh êh-pêy-itisinimiht ôhi êskanah , wîpitah ê-sâmahamoht . The bear had his mouth gaping, and the horn was stuck out at him till it touched his teeth. CHECK Last verb may be a relational instead. HCW: Indefinite agent relational.
cacêmâsinwa ôhi kîpitah ! itêw wîsahkêcâhk . “Those teeth of yours are very short!” Wisahketchahk told him.

seg.q: hâw , ntêskan , wêpahwâhkan awa cacêmâpicis wâkayôs !
seg.gloss: “Now, my Horn, be ready to toss this stubby-tooth bear!
Toss him as soon as he stirs from this spot.
He has delayed me for no reason;

p.seg: êkosi cimahêw ôh êskanah êtiskwêsiniyit . With that, he stuck the horn upright in the ground toward the bear's head, as he was lying.

seg.gloss: “Be ready to toss him, my Horn!
I am going away from here.
You cannot avoid his tossing you.
So then, he will kill you, as soon as you budge!”

p.seg: êkosi cimahêw êkotah . So he stuck it upright there.
nakatêw ; sipwêhtêw . He left it; he went away.

êh-kih-piponiyik , kîhtwâm êh-nîpiniyik ,
mahtih nka-ntawâpamâw nisîm , itêyihtam . When winter had passed and summer had come again, “Suppose I go have a look at my little brother,” he thought.
itohtêw : awîn ôhi ! He went there; what had become of him!
kî-sîkwâhkatosoyiwa ôhi wâkayôsah . That bear had starved to death.

seg.gloss: “Heh! That is what I told you:

seg.q: misawâc ki-waskawiyin , sêmâk ka-kîh-nipahikoh awa nitêskan !
seg.gloss: certainly, if you had budged, at once this Horn of mine would have killed you!”

p.seg: êkosi êkoyikohk êskwâk âtayôhkêwin . That is the end of this sacred story.
